author: Peter Wright
content:
Mon’s Meg, a 20″ bombard made in Belgium in 1457 and gifted to James ii, still fires every day as the famous “1 o’clock gun” from the ramparts of Edinburgh Castle. It was electronically connected to the ball on nearby Carlton Hill that is visible from Leith Docks. When visibility was poor and the drop could not be seen, charts with circles whose diameter were related to the speed of sound in seconds were used to calibrate the chronometer.
The system was also used by hawkers to sell the accurate time to businesses for setting their timepieces that would, for instance, stamp the time for workers clocking on and off.

A Happy New Year to you all!
